content:
âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good contribution.
Will be very tough in reverse mode but because of the negative sign i think it will be doable.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: The minus sign is a nice little twist. I first strictly checked the cases and found the pattern soon enough, so reverse is doable as well.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: This would be best suited for shortest and fastest mode. It would be difficult to think of, but still possible, in reverse mode. I have not seen a puzzle exactly like this one yet.

Validator 1 could be any of ['0+0', '2+4', '3+6', '4+8', '4+12', '5+15', '6+18', '7+21', '8+24', '9+27', '10+40', '11+44', '12+48', '13+52', '14+56', '15+60', '16+64', '17+68', '18+72', '19+76', '20+80', '21+84', '22+88', '23+92', '24+96'] so that if one tries to interpret the expression, at least one Validator works :-)
Why in your solution you do a final loop on "c", instead of just looking at c[0] ?

Without statement the exercise is really devilish ^^

Title
* Please use a more fitting title.

Input
* Please change "equation" to "expression". (An equation should contain an equal sign.)

Input / Output
* Please change 'C' to [[C]] and remove the quotation marks.

Cases
* Please revise Validator 5 and Validator 6 so that the first number in the input consists of more than 1 digit.

Thanks.
Thanks, I will update this right now. If you think anything else has to be updated, let me know because this is my first contribution.
My solution had a loop instead of c[0] because I had earlier tried it and I must have been doing something a little off, for it did not work, but I will fix it so that the solution is much simpler.
And I don't know a name for it. :/
Thank you for the changes. Well, "String length" is already better than "Hi" ðŸ™‚ You may also consider "String length multiplication".

Hey, I have a question about a generator stub on another clach of code im working on. Im wondering if you could help me. Do you know how to make the stub so that inside a loop like this 
- for i in range(n):
             transportation = input()
it could be changed to
-for i in range(n):
            transportation, time = input().split()
my current stub is like this

read distance:int
read n:int
loop n read transportation:string(300)

You may try:
loop n read transportation:word(20) time:int

assuming `transportation` is a string of maximum length of 20 and time is an integer.
Thank you, this is exactly what i needed.
